This is just fantastic! Everyone, including the kids, loved it. I used 2 smaller chuck tender roasts (about 5 1/2 pounds total), 2 cans of Campbell's French onion soup, 1 can of Campbell's Beef Consomme, and 1 bottle of light beer. The beer does add something special--you don't get a "beer" flavor, but you do get a nice rich broth that is surprisingly not too salty. I plan to turn the leftovers into a beef-and-barley soup! Thanks so much for this excellent recipe!

3.6.19  We enjoyed this, but I did think it was longing for some garlic.  Next time I make this, I will cut some slits in the beef, and insert some thin slices of garlic (something my Mother always did with both beef and pork).  Very simple dinner after a full day of yard work.   Enjoyed the sandwich with a slice of mozzarella and quick melt under the broiler then topped with some sliced pepperoncini,  three bean salad, and warmed up scalloped potatoes. I did add a little bit of Kitchen Bouquet® to the au jus to give it a little more eye appeal.   The beef was  tender, moist and easy to slice.  Good slow cooker meal for sure.

text:
Followed several suggestions from reviewers by seasoning the beef prior to placing it in the crockpot.  I used two smaller roasts so I may have exceeded the 4 pounds. My one takeaway is that it truly needs the full 7 hours of cooking time and it could use a little more seasoning/salt. I used a 16 oz can of Coors as that's what I found in the back of my 'fridge.  Next time I'll follow suggestions and use a darker beer.  Putting the buns in the oven made them nice and crusty, perfect for dipping! My family loved it, said it was a keeper recipe!  Thank you  for sharing this recipe.

userID:
8699330
Display Name:
beckytat
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
30
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/779110.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is SO good and SO easy. I used a rump roast and followed a few suggestions made by others. I mixed 1 tsp of garlic powder, 1 tsp of onion powder, a few shakes of salt and ground pepper and rubbed the mix all over my roast. I put it in the crockpot dish and put it in the fridge overnight to let the flavors soak in, but you'd be fine not doing that if you don't have the time. In the morning I added 1 can of beef consomme, 1 can of beef broth, 1 packet of Lipton dried onion soup, 1 can of the darkest beer I could find, and 1 tbls of worcestershire sauce. With one hour left to cook, I took the roast out, sliced it thin, and added it back to the crock for another hour. This made it so juicy and extra flavorful!

For the rolls, I used a very soft hoagie-type roll. I buttered them, added provolone cheese and stuck them under the broiler until they were toasty. This was good, but even with the added crispness from the broiler, I think next time I'll pick a roll with a harder, crunchier crust - I think that would be the best combo with the ajou. Definitely put them in the broiler with cheese, though! mmm!

NOTE ABOUT COOKING TIME: I didn't have one, 4lb rump roast - I had two, approx. 2lb rump roasts - and it definitely did not need 7 hours to cook. Next time, if I'm working with two smaller roasts, I'll probably cook on low for about 4hrs, take it out and slice it and then cook for 1 more hour on low.

I'll definitely be making this again. Thanks everyone for the great su
Review:

userID:
6604672
Display Name:
katrenco

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, very easy, it doesn't get any better.  I used a 2 lb Top Round Roast and a 2 lb Bottom Round, both were good, I like the Bottom Round better as it seemed juicier.  Both were very lean so no grease to deal with in the sauce (which I did strain in a fine strainer before serving).  I cut the beer down to just a little over 1/2 a can and am glad I did, added 1 1/2 T of Worch & 1 T Kitchen Bouquet to the sauce, used 1 can beef broth, 2 cans of condensed French Onion soup + 1 dry pkt of French Onion soup mix dissolved in about 1 1/2 c very hot water.  I rubbed the roasts with garlic & onion powder & Kosher salt then seared on both sides before putting in slow cooker.  Cooked on low for 7 hrs, shredded meat & refrigerated meat in the sauce overnight for guests the next day.  About an hr before serving, I put the juice & meat back into slow cooker to reheat...very tender, juicy and flavorful.  I cut the Hoagie Rolls in half and then split them open, buttered both insides lightly, roasted at 375 (butter side up) for 4 to 5 mins, just until  lightly "crunchy" to hold up under the moist meat (I roasted extra buns for left overs the next day.).  Took buns out after roasting, loaded with meat, topped with Provolone cheese, back in the oven set to broil til cheese melted (watch very closely so they don't burn).  The sandwiches and the sauce were absolutely delicious!  Everyone raved and left overs the next day were marvelous although there wasn't much left, enough for 1 sandwich

This is probably my favorite dish. I make it as often as I can, it's so easy and sooo good. I use Guinness or something dark and syrupy, I've tried lagers and other beers but stouts seem to taste best and give it a richness and dimension of flavor that others don't. I can't recommend this enough, everyone I've ever made it for LOVES it. I do butter the French rolls and sprinkle them generously with garlic salt before toasting them, then melt provolone over top. I want some right now just thinking about it... Leftovers are amazing and you can make some awesome other dishes with them.

text:
I made this a month ago and it was delicious.  I am now making it for Father's Day.  After reading many reviews, I made the following changes:

4 lbs bottom round roast; 
2 cans Campbells Beef Consomme; 
1 pkg dry lipton soup mix; 
12 ozs stout/dark ale; 

Added to top of meat 1/2 tsp of each:
fresh garlic,
garlic powder,
salt,
pepper, and

1 TBSP Worchester Sauce.  

Added a package of sliced mushrooms.

Cooked the meat as stated, removed and sliced thin then added back to juice to cook for 30 minutes longer.

THIS WAS THE BOMB!!!!  Served on rolls with provolone and/or Swiss cheese.

text:
The only problem was the beef was completely shredded after 7 hours. So if you want an actual french dip, roast the meet instead. However, it was AMAZING!

Changes I made from reading reviews:
1. We don't drink at all, so I substituted beer for Pepsi
2. Add 2 tbsp Worcestershire
3. Add 2 tbsp mustard
4. Add 2 tbsp soy sauce
5. Add a pinch of salt and pepper
6. Sautee onions and put in the bottom of the crock pot
7. Add pinches of garlic powder.

This really was delicious!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
O.M.G.  I have made this 3 times already and its a quick way to get rid of slightly over 4 pounds of rump roast quick!  So flavorful, very tender rump roast and moist.  No way to mess this recipe up (and I've tried...forgot to add beer in the morning, remembered in the last 30 minutes so I added it and it still tasted great; probably wouldn't have missed anything other than more juice).  I added enough Worcestershire sauce to cover the roast, along with garlic and onion powder and ground mustard powder.  Husband was amazed at how simple and quick it was to assemble compared to other slow cooker meals.  For the rolls I butter, add McCormick's Garlic Bread Spread powder and toast using the broiler then add whatever kind of cheese I have on hand to the bread, assemble sandwiches and put back into a warm oven for a few minutes.  Amazing how 6 hoagie rolls disappear in a matter of minutes.

text:
This is super easy and so good. Guinness is my choice of beer to use. Any stout is preferred. I actually cook all of my roasts with it, doesn't matter what kind of meat. Anyway, back to the recipe. Sometimes I throw in a packet of dry Itailian dressing. I sear my roast before I put it in the crock pot too. I cook mine low and slow for 8 or more hours. Instead of slicing it, I shred it. Yummers!

country:

text:
Please note that I did some revisions due to previous reviews, and my own substitions but I'm sure the original would be great as well!  I used dry onion soup mix as I couldn't find the can of onion soup in the grocery store I went to, a can of beef consomme, and added sliced onions that I browned in a frying pan.  I took it out with an hour left and sliced the beef, at this point it was already shredding so maybe in the future I would preslice, and also pre cut off fatty bits as there was quite a few of those left but that was from the cut of meat I got.  Husband said he could eat that several times a month, the dipping sauce was very flavourful.  Don't skip out on toasting the buns that made it even better, I toasted them in a frying pan with a bit of butter so I didn't have to heat up the oven.

country:
None
text:
My rating is technically a 4.5 and the only thing keeping it from being 5 star is that it does need tweaked on the seasonings.  I've made this as is and also made with mods.  
After googling rump roast I settled on a bottom round roast.  While I do believe that another cut is probably more flavorful this one slices well with electric knife and is tender.  I do agree with a reviewer who used consommé instead of the broth.  At least 1 tsp salt and W sauce are must haves to make this basic.  My own preferences include garlic and onion powder.  
This has nothing to do with my rating but I suggest making a horseradish mayo and putting provolone on your sandwich.  Very good.

Display Name:
Nisamom
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fantastic!  I use a rump roast, personally like that it is less fatty than the chuck.  Followed to the letter the first time with great results, and subsequently added minced garlic (2-3 cloves), worcestershire (several shakes, probably around 1/2 tsb - but we love this in our beef stew, do to taste) and added some pepper to the roast before pouring in the soup/beer.  There is enough salt in the soup, IMO, I personally wouldn't add more unless you like extra salt.  I toasted cheese onto the french rolls as suggested (have used both mozzarella and white cheddar, both were great).   I also followed the suggestion of saving the extra gravy and adding mushrooms the following night, amazing over noodles!!!  My kids could not eat this fast enough.

text:
Ummmm-mazing!  I'm not even a fan of french dips!  Bits of advice-- It took longer for my beef to cook.  Well, I did a full 7 1/2 hrs, and then put it in another 1/2 hr after slicing.  I seasoned the beef with what I had on hand-- onion powder, garlic powder, salt, pepper, parsley & threw several shakes of worchestershire sauce into it.  Used regular beef broth, condensed french onion soup, an amber beer.  Slice the beef THIN!!!

I didn't' put butter on our buns, and it was still amazing. I served it with a dipping sauce that I thought was mind-blowing.  Just grabbed some of the broth from the crock pot, and added a squeeze of japanese wasabi and a couple of splashes of red wine vinegar.  Everyone was in LOVE  This is a big-time keeper!

text:
Husband and I loved this. Slow cooked for about 8 hours, it was fall apart tender. Advice I followed from previous reviewers: used 6 ounces of beer not 12 (hubby doesn't like the taste of beer), added 1 tsp each of onion powder, garlic powder and worcestershire sauce. Once meat was sliced I put back into cooker to soak up more juice while I buttered and heated up rolls. Then placed meat on heated rolls, topped with provalone cheese slices and put under the broiler for a few minutes. So good! Will definitely add to the regular rotation of meals.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2013-10-14T17:51:14.41
helpfulCount:

userID:
1831377
Display Name:
Texasgirl@heart
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
71
favoritesCount:
498

0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/18.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe using a 3 pound sirloin tip roast.  I seasoned my roast with onion powder, garlic powder, seasoning salt, black pepper, cayenne pepper and sea salt then I browned it in a frying pan with a little oil before putting it in the crockpot.  After that step, I followed the recipe exactly as written, adding the meat to the crockpot with the beef broth and french onion soup and a 16 ounce can of Miller High Life beer (a stray beer my 21 year old son left in the fridge LOL).  I pulled the roast out after 5 hours and sliced it and put it back in the crockpot for an hour with the crockpot set on warm.  I buttered my french rolls and sprinkled a little garlic salt on them and put them in the oven at 350 degrees for 10 minutes and then pulled them out, put meat on them and topped them with slices of mozzarella cheese and put them back in the oven under the broiler for a couple of minutes to melt the cheese.  I served them with fried mushrooms, and individual bowls of au jus on the side to dip them in.  The meat turned out very moist and tender but we all felt like they were just missing something, we just couldn't figure out what.  They were lacking in flavor and my son said they tasted just like pot roast on a bun.  I would probably make them again but they are not my favorite and I will probably try the other recipe on this site for french dip sandwiches made with soy sauce and rosemary.

text:
The first time I made this as is it was good,but far from great. Though it had potential. If you aren't making this last minute I highly recommend you use leftover french onion soup rather than can. The day before I make this, I'll make slow cooker french onion soup for dinner and reserve some for this recipef. I omit the beef broth from this recipe. But follow the rest of this recipe accordingly and add either swiss or monterey jack cheese. It's flawless, best sandwich I've ever had.. AINEC. Of course it isn't as quick as the original, but it's worlds better, and in turn you get two excellent meals already planned for the week.

vhbjohnson

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is what got us hooked on allrecipes.com.  This is an amazing starting off point for french dip sandwiches.  We like to add: fresh garlic, use beef consomme instead of the beef broth, couple shakes of Worchestershire, fresh ground pepper, onion powder.  Canned french onion soup works better than dry mix, dark beer better than light.  We've made this so many times over the last 3 years and it's never once turned out anything less than delicious. We always start a large batch late the night before and let it cook through the night on low (leaving it on low or warm during the day) until serving for dinner.  No need to slice the meat because it just falls a part on it's own.  Freezes beautifully, so we eat a little and freeze the rest.  LOVE love love this recipe!

text:
I've had this recipe several times with different cuts of meat (chuck included). I finally was able to find the rump roast it calls for and made it that way, it was by far the best cut of meat for this recipe. And I usually cook it 8 hours then the crockpot keeps it on warm for an hour or more. I don't butter the rolls, though. Very easy, very delicious, and not too hefty on the calories either. Love it. Oh, and I think the flavor of the broth depends on the kind of beer you use. I used Sam Adams light.

text:
This recipe is fantastic! It's the first recipe I've ever reviewed but it was so amazing, I just had to take a moment to type this up. I followed the recipe almost exactly and my whole family (including two hard to please kids) LOVED it. They thanked me over and over for making it and have requested it again ASAP. The only changes were that I used a sirloin tip roast, seasoned it with a little garlic powder, salt and pepper and used a can of Guinness Draught for the beer. I cooked it all day and it was falling apart by 4:30. I did as some of the other reviewers suggested and sliced/shredded it and let it simmer in the juice for about 30 minutes before I served. It was soooo good!!

Great dinner! 
I rate this recipe 5 stars.

userID:
9275399
Display Name:
PSKITTY
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:

0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I do a couple of things include cut an onion into rings and saute in butter 'til caramelized. I use a carton of beef broth and a package of onion soup mix and a bottle of good beer.  I'm not into cans!

I use a 3lb London broil

Put all ingredients in a slow cooker on high until meat is fork-tender and ready. 5-6 hours. Halfway through, taste the sauce and adjust spices, add more broth if needed. Pull the meat apart right in the cooker, remove all fat and let the meat rest a couple of minutes. You don't even need teeth, it's so tender!

text:
I make this regularly now and refuse to share the recipe! lol...have to keep them coming back right?! I use Guinness...darker the beer the better...for those who don't like beer (I hate it...you don't taste beer)!  If in a jam I will use french onion soup mix dissolved in a cup of boiling water...sometimes I add a little spanish onion and always half a tsp of paprika. It works well with any meat but the key is definately to take it out...cut it up and return it to the cooker to simmer another while!  Hope you all enjoy this as much as I do! Oh...I have tried many varieties of cheese on this under the broiler...I vote provlerone like many others here!  Thanks lonwolf32.

You've got to be KIDDING me, right?! Someone please pinch me so I know I'm not dreaming! This is absolutely THE best French dip I've ever had!!! And I've had some pretty awesome French dip sandwiches in my lifetime. My husband, who never usually has the au jus with his sandwiches, was converted into a dipper! I must say, I am not a beer fan at all and was quite hesitant about adding the beer (I used Guinness), especially after smelling it I thought I ruined the whole thing. But it really adds a wonderful flavor. I added some garlic powder and just a few splashes of soy sauce for extra flavor. I made French baguettes from this website to serve the meat on. I cannot wait for dinner tonight so I could have the leftovers!!

text:
Awesome!  Followed recipe, but didn’t have 7 hours to cook.  Placed everything in my Nesco 6qt roaster for about 3 1/2 hours at 350 then turned down to 300 until ready to serve.  After toasting the rolls, I placed the meat on the buns, covered with muenster cheese and put under the broiler to melt.  I then gave them a generous smear of of Adzel's Creamy Horseradish Garlic Spread from this site and served with a ramekin of au jus for dipping.  The contrast of the zesty, cold horseradish spread with the hot meat and au jus was absolutely delicious!

text:
5 plus ++ I knew this was going to be a yummy meal. This recipe smells and tastes so wonderful. I could smell it cooking from outside the house.  The night before I seasoned meat with a little blk pepper, rock salt and stuck some garlic cloves in the meat. I was only feeding two people so I had a smaller chuck roast, about 2.5 pounds. I put the roast in the slow cooker on LOW for 8 hours and used a can of Heinekin beer (that is all I had). Meat was so soft it fell apart and was juicy and tender but tasty..yum! After I sliced and shredded the meat I placed back in the juice to let it soak up. The french dip was so succulent and the french bread rolls to die for soaked up the dip nicely...I will definitely make this again and again!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fabulous!  I followed the suggestions of others and used a can of beef consomme and a can of onion soup (didn't use beer as we didn't have any in the house at the time).  I started by seasoning the roast with Montreal Steak Seasoning.  I then poured the soups over and added three sliced cloves of garlic.  Next time I'll throw in some sliced onions as well.  Cooked on low for 9 hours then removed roast, sliced thin, strained liquid and returned the roast to the liquid and continued to cook on low for another 30+ minutes.  Served on hoagies with provolone cheese and tucked under the broiler just long enough to melt the cheese.  Au jus was perfect!  Super easy and yummy!

text:
After reading other reviews I seasoned the roast with salt and pepper before starting and added 2 cloves of garlic to the slow cooker.
The meat was still a little bland, but when put on a toasted bun with a little garlic butter and dipped in the jus, it was very good. Will definatly do it again, but I'll season it a little more next time. Maybe a little more garlic as well.
After a few more months of eating this on a regular basis, I've made a couple other changes. The roast is well seasoned with salt pepper and garlic powder. I also add a few cloves of minced garlic to the juice. Some worcestershire sauce as well.

text:
This was fantastic! My store didn't have rump roast so I used bottom round, but I think you could use chuck or just about any sort of roast with this recipe. I added a few splashes of worcestershire sauce and I used a dark Guinness for the beer. I bought some french rolls from the bakery for the sandwiches, spread a small amount of butter on them and toasted them in the broiler for a couple of minutes, then topped with provolone cheese and broiled a couple more minutes until it melted, then piled on the meat. Wonderful recipe, and I will definitely make it again. My husband loved it!

Made it the day before.  Took the meat out and refrigerated it.  In the morning sliced up the cold meat, skimmed the fat off the sauce and put meat back in sauce to reheat.  Buttered good hero bread, put thick slice of Provelone on and melted it.  Placed meat on with sauteed onions on top. Meat was tender but bland.  Will try again but will add garlic, pepper and some Worchestire sauce.   Might add a drop of hot sauce to the sauce too.

text:
Great recipe to base your version of it on.  I seared the roast with some salt, pepper, onion and garlic powders, then used one can of beef connsumme instead of the beef broth with the french onion soup, and bought a sirloin tip roast instead of a rump roast. I also had it in the crock pot a lot longer. Soaking the slices before serving is KEY! I soaked ours for a good 20-30 minutes before serving and it paid off. So good. Served on french rolls with butter & mozz cheese under the broiler. As we say in my family, this one's a keeper.

I have used frozen and fresh roasts with equally delicious results.  My children often request this as their birthday dinner.  The results far exceed the effort required to make it!

text:
This was good....I used the roast it called for very leary b/c it always turns out really dry.  I put it in my crockpot frozen & cooked it 2 hours less than stated & it was still dry.  I sliced it thin & put it back in the juices but that didn't help much.  I did fix a sandwich for my husband later & for me the next day & warmed up with some cheese melted over the top did make it more moist.  Next time I will use a chuck roast or at least one that isn't such a dry roast to begin with.  I did saute some mushrooms in the juice from the roast & they were EXCELLENT that way!  I will definitely be making this again but not with the suggested cut of meat. Thanks for a good one!

text:
USED CHUCK ROAST (ON SALE)- ADDED MINCED GARLIC AND WORCHESTSHIRE---  MADE ONE DAY, TOOK UP ROAST AND PLACED AU JUS IN ANOTHER CONTAINER.. NEXT NIGHT , TOOK OUT ROAST BEEF AND SLICED VERY THIN ( YOU CAN DO THAT EASIER OUT OF THE FRIG)- WARMED IN A LITTLE OF THE JUS, (ALSO LETS YOU REMOVE FAT OFF TOP OF JUS WHEN COLD)- SERVED ON BUTTERED WARMED ROLLS FROM THE PUBLIX BAKERY WITH SMOKED PROVOLONE AND JUS ON SIDE...  YUM....   I THOUGHT IT NEED SALT AT SERVING (YEAH, I KNOW, LOOK AT THAT SODIUM CONTENT ON THAT CAN!! ) YEAH, WHATEVER - I ADDED A LITTLE GARLIC SALT ON MINE...  VERY EASY, VERY GOOD..  THANKS

text:
The good thing about this recipe is that it makes an au jus sauce like a french dip. I also never heat baked rolls before to use them for a sandwich, and that was a good idea.  However, the roast cooked in a liquid the thickness of water and the meat shredded when done instead of slicing.  In addition, the flavor of the meat was no different than when I cook a pot roast.  I was hoping the liquid would season the meat more than the beef in a pot roast, which usually needs gravy.  I might try next time just making au jus dip on the stove and then using a different more flavorful and sliceable roast beef recipe dry roasted in the oven.

I used two chuck steaks that I seared first before putting in the slow cooker; I think the bones and extra fat of the chuck steak gave it delicious extra flavor that you wouldn't necessarily see with a roast.  I will definitely use this recipe again as a base for other meals (beef stroganoff, rouladen, etc).

text:
I started making this a few years ago and it is now a family staple.  We spray the rolls with olive oil and then sprinkle minced garlic over that.  Broil the buns until they're toasted.  Then, I slice the beef and add it to one half of the bun, placed sliced swiss cheese over it, and put it back under the broiler until the cheese bubbles a little.  Take it out of the oven and add the other half of the bun and voila!

Display Name:
Rose

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great! I went to the meat counter in the grocery store to ask where I could find a "rump roast" and the butcher said that bottom roast is bascially the same. He said that "rump roast" is an older term for a cheaper cut of meat they would tie up with a bunch of seasonings inside, but that they rarely sell those anymore and a bottom roast seasoned properly would produce the same results if not better. So i used this recipe on a 3.5 lb bottom roast.  Followed the recipe exactly after I flipped the roast 1/2 way through the cooking time, i realized the juice wasn't quite salty enough for our taste so I just added a little seasoned salt, garlic peper & garlic salt. finished cooking and it came out amazing!  Everyone loved it, and wanted seconds! The extra seasoning was the only thing I changed. I used a budweiser can of beer, but i think any beer would be fine, perhaps staying away from a light beer. The beer and onion flavors mixed so nice together, I was so incredibly surprised how good this was because it was Sooooo easy! Definetly a keeper!

I'm only giving this 4 stars because I found the au jus to be very bland when prepared as directed.  However, after adding a few things it came out almost perfect.  I added a few cloves of chopped garlic as well as a dash of garlic powder, a couple dashes or worcestershire sauce, some beef boullion flavoring, and some thyme.  Other changes I made were to use a dark beer, and yes the whole bottle... I can always taste beer in a recipe but I honestly could not in this one.  I did attempt to stir out most of the carbonation at the end though.  I also peppered and seared the roast prior to placing in it the crock pot.  I had no problem slicing it as some people had mentioned.  It did seem dry as I was slicing, but was fine after being replaced into the au just for another 30 or 45 minutes.  I also chose to broil the bread with swiss cheese, and added sauteed green peppers and onions.  The only changes I would make next time would be to cook it low and slow... I cooked it on a higher heat for 5 to 6 hours this time.  Also, I may try beef consomme as some of you mentioned you did.  Or, I would prepare as I did this time but would get low sodium broth since I would be adding the beef boullion.  Provolone cheese would also be a better choice as it is fuller flavored.  Overall though, very good recipe... my fiance loved it and that says a lot...

Unreal!!!!  This is a top notch dinner and so easy you feel like your cheating. This will be a recipe that you use over and over and over again... TRUST ME, ITS THAT GOOD!

My local grocer hardly ever has rump roast, so I purchase a top or bottom round. No difference in quality. I always use a darker beer, usually Shiner Bock or Guinness. text:
My family loved this!  I did sub the consomme for the beef broth and I think it gave it a richer flavor.  I also left out the beer (drank it all the night before oops!) and I think it was great even without it.  I also followed others advice and added the onion powder, garlic powder, oregano, rosemary, worcestershire, soy sauce.  I think it would have been a little bland without it.  I also added provolone cheese to the subs when assembling.  This one is a keeper!

text:
We made two roasts for our daughers' birthday party.  We cooked them, sliced the roasts thin, put the meat back in the juice and refrigerated the meat and juice the day before the party.  The day of the party we put the meat and juice back in the crockpot on low until the party started.  We had rolls and shredded mozzarella cheese set out with the meat and the sandwiches were a HUGE hit.  Will definitely be making again and again.

text:
This was really good, and after making it plenty of times now I prefer to use chuck steaks and trim all the fat off.   Also, it definitely needs spices added.  I used Dried MInced onion, onion and garlic powder and even some garlic salt and table salt / pepper blend.  I added a little spices then let it cook and then adjusted for flavor with about an hour left to cook.  Definitely serve on fresh hoagie rolls so they soak up all the juices!

text:
I added a few more seasonings based on the reviews. I did not put so much beer in, and I am very grateful. A fourth of a cup was really all it needed. I added about a can and a half of lower sodium beef broth, a tablespoon of Worcestershire, a 1/2 teaspoon of garlic powder, pepper, onion powder, and Italian seasonings. I also added about a half packet of onion soup mix. While this was good, I would not say it was outstanding. I would make it again, but eat it as a roast instead of on sandwiches.

text:
This was fantastic! Slight variations from the recipe..* Used 5lb. rump roast trimmed all fat and rubbed generously w/ pepper and garlic granules. * 6oz. Newcastle Brn. Ale/6 oz. beef stock * Substitu te 1 can beef consomme' for beef broth. *2 tsp. worchestire. * Cooked on low 8 hrs, sliced meat & returned to low for 1 more hour. *Packaged Au Jus prepared seperately(for the dipping sauce)using 1 cup beef stock/2cups water because that gave us the more traditional "dip flavor" we love. Melted provolone on top. Just like the real thing :)

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2008-10-10T09:36:15.843
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
3041937
Display Name:
chrismturner
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
38
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/124608.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a really great recipe. I prepared the meat the night before. I didn't have the onion soup mix, typically try to stay from the powdered mix because many contain MSG. Instead I sliced a whole onion and sauteed the onion with a few sliced garlic cloves in olive oil just until translucent. Place the prepared onion and garlic in the bottom of the slow cooker. I placed my frozen, yes frozen, roast on top. Sprinkle with dried oregano, basil, thyme, salt and pepper. Add a liberal amount of Worcestershire sauce(three to four good shakes) and about 1/4 cup soy sauce. Cover the roast with canned beef stock and set on low. My whole house smelled like a Sunday pot roast. When I woke the next morning, the roast was completely cooked to the point of falling apart. I gently shredded the meat, leaving it in the juices all day until serving time(my slow cooker has a 'warm' setting). We served the meat on toasted whole wheat hoagie rolls. 

I used the left over meat to make a tasty Shepherds Pie the next night. I will definitely use this recipe again!

text:
These are SO good, and so easy! I used a rump roast. It was too hard to trim the fat before cooking, so I waited until after and it came right off. I sliced it with an electric knife and returned it to the juices for about 30 minutes. I used fresh vienna rolls frm the bakery, and I followed the recipe and put butter and provolone on them. Then I put them under the broiler for a couple minutes. These were a hit in my house-I will be making them again and again!

Wow! I used a 2 lb sirloin roast and when I cut it after 4 hrs, it was difficult to cut and not very tasty, didnt think I would like it at all. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is so easy and so good.  The fat on the rump roast  gives the juice a really good flavor.  Splurge and don't skim off the fat.  I sliced my beef thin with a meat slicer and  topped with sweet onion and a slice of provolone cheese. Then put it under the broiler just till the cheese melted.   I used a  good sub bun.   With the leftover's, I froze in a plastic container and when it was froze solid, I removed from container and vacuum packed it with my Food Saver.   Now when I'm lazy all I have to do is thaw it out in the  Microwave. I am really looking forward to having it again.  My husband said I should  always make my rump roast like this. He couldn't stop raving about it.

text:
Quick, easy, and yummy. My kind of meal. Well, let me rephrase the quick part...the preparation is quick, but the cooking is slow...which isn't a bad thing. The slow cooking makes the meat nice and tendar. 
The only thing I did differently is I chopped up an onion and added it to the broth, added a bit of water so the meat was completely covered, then added some beef bouillon, added a little bit of garlic powder, and a bit of worceshtershire (I can never spell that darn word).

Everyone LOVED it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is excellent! The meat was so tender I couldn't even slice it - it just fell apart. 

After reading the reviews, I decided to try this with the rump roast (instead of chuck roast) recommended in the original recipe. I had no problems with it being too fatty. To enhance flavor, I sprinkled the roast with salt and pepper and then browned it on sides in a skillet. I then deglazed the skillet with the beer and scraped up the brown "flavor bits" with a wooden spoon, added the beef broth, and once it was warm poured it all over the browned roast in the crock pot. I put in the condensed soup and eight hours later, everyone was raving. Plus, the house smelled great all day! This is definitely my new favorite for crock-pot french dip.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were VERY good...I was pleasantly surprised.  Here is what I did:  I made this with a 3 lb Rump Roast & cooked the roast for 5 hours, removed it from the crock pot & let it rest for about 20 minutes.  I then sliced it..when I was slicing it, it seemed kind of dry, so if it seems that way when slicing it, don't worry. I then returned the slices to the liquid in the crock pot for about 1 hour.  To prepare the sandwiches, I cut the french rolls in half & put butter on each side.  Then, I added beef to one side & put cheese on top of it...I actually used Pepper Jack & it was yummy.  I then put the sandwiches (open faced) in an oven pre-heated to 375 just until the cheese melted.  The rolls got a little toasted, but not too much.  This is the best crock pot recipe I have ever made!

Oh yea! I agree with the one that says if you could give it 10 stars I would! I used a rump roast from our quarter of beef we have. I'm sure 90% of this recipe depends on the quality of the beef you use. This one turned out SO PERFECT! There was not a single bit of toughness to this meat, it practically melted in my mouth it was so tender. My husband goes down in the books as the pickiest eater. He said this was "by far the best french dip" he has ever had! I seasoned the beef with some garlic powder and black pepper. Next time I will add a touch of salt. I followed everyone elses advice and put the cheese and butter on the buns and toasting them. This recipie was SO easy and convienient it may just have to become a weekly thing at our house this winter! Also, it is such a versitile recipe as far as the left overs go. Tonight I will be using the beef and some of the sauce to make a beef stroganoff! Thank you for the recipe!

text:
I used the leftovers to make a Beefy French Onion Soup last night.  I added a can of condensed French Onion soup to the broth and re-heated on the stovetop.  I skimmed of the layer of fat that had collected on the top before heating.  While the soup heated I placed a slice of French bread in the bowls ladled the heated soup over the top then topped with slices of Munster cheese.  I placed the bowls under the broiler until the cheese was bubbly and browned along the edges.  My son thought it was just OK but my husband and I loved it!  He says that I'm very sneaky using leftovers, but he did like what I transformed the French Dip sandwiches into.  So the nice thing is that I got two totatlly different meals out of one recipe.  Gotta love that.

text:
I was happy with the result of this recipe (even though I didn't have any beer to use in the cooking liquid). I was concerned because some reviewers said it tasted like pot roast and I definitely didn't want pot roast! I used a sirloin tip and it wasn't "pot roasty" at all. I am sure that if you use chuck roast, you WILL get pot roast! DH liked it a lot, he doesn't like deli roast beef for French dip, so this is great. Was making this off the pantry shelf, so I used canned beef broth, dry Lipton onion soup (which I won't do again, it has a bitter overbearing taste!) and a package of au jus to make up for no beer. I'll buy the correct ingredients needed to try it per the recipe next time.

text:
This is SO delicious!  I used a sirloin tip roast, seasoned it with garlic powder and pepper, used a full-bodied beer and strained out the onions from the soup.  It does not need any salt – there’s enough in the broth and soup.  About 30 minutes before it was done, sliced thinly and returned to au jus to finish.  I used hoagie rolls, covered top half with provolone slices (no butter) and toasted under the broiler.  Added the beef and stacked it all together.  Tender and plenty of flavor – after trying several other French dip recipes, my boyfriend said this one was a keeper!

text:
After making this several times, we've still not been able to decide which the best cut of meat is for this dish. The rump roast left a lot of fat in the au jus. We've had good luck with a tri-tip. Also found that the cheaper and lighter the beer, the better. Recommend adding a powdered Au Jus mix (Lawry's or Schilling) to the liquid for added flavor.

To the person who rated this as 1 star.We obviously each have our own opinions so I respect the fact that you didn't like the french dip. However you must have had a bad cut of meat because I have made it twice, my mom has made it twice and my sister in law once and we have all had very tender beef. I added worchestire sauce. I like things with a lot of favour so I get you on that one, but I have made it with home made french onion soup (onions, one garlic clove, beef broth, worchesterchire, and pepper and that turned out well.

Try it that way. I pretty sure it was the meat you got from the butcher. I have had tough meat before. It would not have been your cooking method since slow cookers are reliable so that is all I can think of.

Leanne

This was excellent.  Didn't change a thing.  Used a heavier beer, Fat Tire.  Gives it a robust flavor. Family loved it, shared recipe with extended family. 12/20/08 update: Served at a family Xmas dinner this last weekend. They thought it was prime rib. Lots of compliments. text:
Wow  great recipe! I couldn't find a rump roast so I substituted two  2.5 lbs round roasts since I was having guests over.  I sprinkled the meat with garlic salt and then seared them in a little oil before putting in the crock pot.  Even though I had more meat than the recipe calls for, I still only used one can each of the soups and  one can of beer.  I did use one package of au jus and a few splashes of worstershire   sauce to taste.  My guests all liked it very much and asked for the recipe.  I feel like the dipping sauce was a little salty but still very good.  I may use garlic powder next time. The meat does get very tender so it makes sense to slice before it's done, but no one cared that the meat was more shredded than sliced.  It was a hit. Thanks I'll be making this one again.  UPDATE: 8/31/13 - used a 5 lb brisket and worked great, this time just used garlic powder and Worcestershire sauce on the meat before pouring the soups and beer!  Sliced it after about 8 hours and added it back to the juice.  SO GOOD!

country:
None
text:
MMMM,MMMM good! These are great and sooo easy! I did add au jus mix, as suggested by others, and the sauce was extremely flavorful. My husband usually likes grilled onions on his sandwiches, but these had such onion flavor he did not need them. I tried these with and without provolone cheese, and must say that with the au jus mix included you don't notice the cheese at all because the juice is so flavorful(save some calories). Also, don't make the mistake of thinking your roast is done before the full seven hours of cooking is complete. I got a little nervous because four hours into cooking my roast was cooked and seems a little dry. However, I let it cook the full seven hours and the meat ended up tender and juicy.

text:
800 people can't be wrong about this, so the purpose of my review is to warn you to follow this recipe closely because you can screw it up!  My changes apparently kept this from turning out as well as I had hoped.  First, use the cut of meat specified. I used a top round (very lean) cut and it was tough at first, so I cooked it longer and then it became really dry. Also, I threw in a 14.5 ounce can of reduced salt beef broth instead of 10.5 ounce and I think it diluted the flavor of the French onion too much. The broth was pretty bland,so I would probably not use the reduced sodium next time, either.

This was a very good meal. I didn't have as long to let it cook so I used my electric knife and sliced the meat before cooking. I took out the onion soup and used 1/3 c soy sauce and enough worchestershire to total 1/2 c instead.  I also omitted the butter for the bread and added thyme, rosemary and garlic powder to the juice then strained it when it was done cooking.  I didn't have that much roast either so I used a 1 1/2 pound venison roast that I cut up in small pieces and browned before I put it in the crockpot.  This recipe was absolutely delicious!  Thank you!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2272847.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Reduce the FAT!!!!

This recipe is GREAT, if you are looking for a way to cut down on the fat, try the method I just used, it works perfectly.

After the roast is done cooking, allow some time for the broth to cool.  Then fill a large ziploc bag with ice.  Seal the bag and immerse it in the broth (if the broth is too hot, it will likely melt the bag).  The bag will latch onto the fat, after you are done, throw the bag away.

Once you have reduced enough fat, put the broth back in the crock pot for 5-10 minutes in order to heat it back up.  

Give it a try and let me know how it worked for you!

This recipe is a definite keeper.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Did someone say "Accidental" Slow Cooker French Dip recipe?  The box of French Onion Soup mix that I had on hand also happened to contain a free full-sized sample package of Ranch Dip mix.  You guessed it.  I pulled a pack out, opened it up and dumped it into the liquid - and it didn't look like onion soup mix!  It did, however, add an additional interesting flavor to the broth and might be something someone would consider doing on purpose if you think the recipe is "bland" without additional flavor.  I didn't want it to be a huge mistake, though, so I did also add a package of onion soup mix with about 2 cups more of water.  I didn't have time to use the slow cooker, though, so cooked it in the pressure cooker and it came out superb just the same!  (For high altitude: I pressure cooked for 1-1/4 hours instead of the 60 minutes called for in my pressure cooker cookbook for a pot roast.)  I browned the meat in the pressure cooker before adding the liquid and also sauted a large sweet onion (cut in thin slices) in the pan before adding the juices.  I used a 12-oz bottle of "Loft" by New Belgium Brewing.  Everyone thinks it's great - and the aroma in the house is divine!

Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good, after some work.  I bought the rump roast and seasoned it with salt and pepper then put it in the crock with light beer and a can of french onion soup.  I cooked it on low all day into the night, then unplugged the crock.  The next day, I turned it back on and tested the meat.  It was VERY tough and the juice tasted very strongly of beer.  I removed the roast and sliced it with an electric meat slicer, very thin.  I poured the sauce into a sauce pan and boiled it to burn off the beer flavor, then added another can of french onion soup.  I carmelized 4 onions and added them to the sauce and continued to cook on slow for another couple of hours. I heated the french rolls and added provolone cheese slices to each roll then put the meat in.  Served on a plate with the sauce in a small ramekin for dipping.  Was very good!

text:
I've been making this for over a year now.  Everyone in my family just loves it.  I don't always use rump roast though, it can be very expensive when it's not on sale.  Also, rump roast can be somewhat tough & chewy so I've experimented with other cuts of meat.  I guess what I'm trying to say is the flavor is always wonderful but the texture can vary, depending on what cut of meat you use.  It's a simple, no fuss recipe.  Thanks Robin!

text:
Robyn Bloomquist!
Thank you for this easy recipe.  We added some carrots, onion and celery to it and slow baked it over night because our slow cooker was too small for this size roast.  My husband doesn't like beer in any form, so we used a nice shiraz in it's place.  We stopped cooking it after 5 hrs and let it cool to cut it and then let it cook another 2 hrs.  It was so good and filling.  We made burritos out of the leftover meat and french onion soup out of the leftover broth.  
Thank You!  Thank You!  Thank You!

Display Name:
holly

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7646987.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this. My family loved this. I don’t venture too far from my usual repertoire of the same 5 recipes, but I wanted to try something new. If I can make this, you can make this. I followed the recipe exactly as written, except that due to taking my 80 year old mom to her doctor appt and running the teen to youth group it was in the slow cooker on low for 7:35hr and on warm for about 3 additional hours. I figured it was doomed, but sliced the meat and returned to the juice for another hour while tending to the dog who just had surgery. Sautéd a yellow onion, toasted the open face of the buns in a skillet, added meat, layered the onions, put two slices of provolone on top and placed under the broiler until bubbly and browned. These words can’t out of my husbands mouth: “this is the best French dip I’ve ever had”. Paired well with Simply Lemonade & vodka.

text:
I have made this recipe at least 5 times in the last couple of years. It is absolutely delicious! I follow the recipe. My husband always trims as much of the fat off of the rump roast as possible. However, I make homemade French Onion soup, courtesy of Tyler Florence from the Food Network (Which I make several personal adjustments to), the day before. I feel that the homemade French onion soup is my key to perfect the flavor to my palate. However, next time, I may try using a different cut as recommended by some other reviews. 

This recipe is delicious! I know, it's redundant. I don't care. My husband always looks so forward to this meal!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loved these sandwiches.  I don't have beer at my house so I left it out.  I had only a 2 1/2 # roast so I didn't use as much liquid.  I used 1 packet of Lipton onion soup mix, added 3 cups water, 2 beef bouillon cubes, 2 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce. and I sprinkled the roast with some pepper and dried minced garlic (about 1/2 tsp of each).  I got it started a little late so I cooked on high in the slow-cooker.  It was done in 5 hours.  I served them on homemade buns, some of my family put cheese on them, too.  I'm sure I'll make this again.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I have made it twice now and everyone who has it loves it! I use whatever inexpensive beef roast I can find, the bottle of beer, beef both and pecker packer of dried onion soup ( because the soup I dry, I double the beef broth). I serve it with ciabatta buns, cheese, sauteed mushrooms and horse radish as well as butter and a sprinkle or garlic salt on the buns, as per another review. I like to dip mine in the juice, whereas my husband likes to be pour some juice inside n his sandwich. Either way, it's delicious and willy continue to be a popular meal in our house!

I made this but substituted 2 sirloin roasts to lower the fat content. The roast was slightly dry by itself but the au jus more than compensated. If I'd been able to purchase one large roast instead of 2 small ones, it may not have been dry at all.  I froze several packets with 2 portions of beef for future meals and equal portions of au jus to go with each. Easy meals for the future.

This was wonderful. We like our food well seasoned, so I seasoned the roast prior to putting it in the crockpot. I didn't have beer so I omitted that. I used Lipton dry onion soup mix and Better than Bouillon beef base in place of the broth and onion soup. It was terrific. We actually ate it for dinner 2 nights and for 1 lunch. I will be making this again for sure.

Display Name:
meggan

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I added a few things and changed a few also. Instead of French onion condensed soup I added two packets of Lipton beefy onion, 1/4 c of soy sauce, and 3 beef bullion cubes. I put it in the slow cooker overnight for 7 hours on low, then let it cool and refrigerated it in the morning until afternoon. Took it out of the fridge and took out the fat and grease and put it in the stove to simmer and cook down for better flavor. I also used a fresh French bread loaf and toasted it in the oven. Afterward I cut it up into sandwich sizes, put Swiss cheese on each piece and broiled them in the toaster oven and after served with au jus. My husband said that this is the best French dip he has ever had and the best thing I have ever made for dinner. My picky 7 year old kept saying how delicious it was! I think that leaving it in the fridge to seal in the flavor and then reducing the sauce with the meat on the stove made it better than ever.

text:
Holy moly!! This was so so GOOD!! I did take the time to read numerous reviews, listened to the advice given, made some tweaks suggested by reviewers and HALLELUJAH.... This was a winner! I used approximately 1/3 of a can of beer. I wasn't able to find a really dark beer as suggested (can't find those easily when just wanting one can) so I used a lighter beer I had on hand. I don't think it made a huge difference because this was still really good. I rubbed the roast with garlic powder, used a half of an envelope of Lipton Onion Soup Mix, a little Worcestire, beef stock, a little Better than Bullion, a packet of au ju, and time. Don't rush this recipe. Just let it sit in the crock pot and leave it alone. I mean it! Don't lift the lid to get closer to the heavenly smell coming out of there! I am such a fan of this recipe! I'm going to be making this one again and again.

userID:
22485649
Display Name:
Andrew Theis
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty solid. I made it according to the recipe using Guinness Draught, and it smelled fantastic while it was cooking. When I tasted it as I shredded the meat the flavor was just okay. Per other comments I added garlic powder and onion powder as well as a little bit of worcestershire sauce but it still wasn't right. I could tell it wasn't sweet enough for French onion soup so I ended up adding a few teaspoons of sugar which helped some but didn't entirely fix it and then I had my wife taste it and she said it wasn't oniony enough or salty enough. So with the addition of a hefty amount of onion salt we ended up with a  good product. My only other gripe is that I read the comment suggesting provolone cheese and so bought that but I remember eating french onion soup with swiss cheese somewhere and I tried that second and it was fantastic! So final notes: Onion salt not powder, garlic powder, sugar if needed, worcestershire, and SWISS for the win. And I was adding stuff at the end so be conservative with your amounts if you're starting that way.

5

text:
I’ll be making this over and over again. I didn’t make the original but took most of the advice in the comments for making this and wouldn’t change a single thing. 

I changed the meat because the one in the recipe wasn’t available at my store, and the beef chuck was the recommended replacement. The beer was a really great touch. It was so, so good.

I added fresh minced garlic and some salt and pepper along with a couple shakes of Worcestershire sauce. I removed and cut the meat around 6hrs and threw it back in for the last hour which really added flavor to it.

Finally, I got some sourdough hoagies and melted provolone cheese on them in the broiler and added butter.

I’ll be making this again and again!

userID:

Display Name:
THE BEAVER FAMILY
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I needed to make this gluten free, so I could not use the French Onion Dip as it has gluten in it.  So I sliced up a yellow onion and added that to the beef stock (gluten free stock), I also used a gluten free dark beer.  I added 1 teaspoon of minced garlic.  I also used a Chuck Roast as rump roasts are harder to find.  Chuck makes the meat more like pulled pork in texture.

I cannot get over how good this tastes.  Excellent recipe.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-05-16T06:55:28.213

text:
This was a great recipe to have cooking all day on a Sunday.  I wasn't able to slice the roast after it was cooked, so we ended up with more of a shredded beef, but the flavor was amazing.  I used a dark porter for the beer, and although you couldn't taste the beer, the caramel-ish flavor that it gave was very tasty.  We paired it with crispy french fries (also tasty in the au jus) and a caesar salad.  What a great meal with little effort, thanks to the slow cooker!

userID:
21059365
Display Name:
kapnkendall
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
24
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a perfectly fine starting place.  To make it better I use a dark beer or stout, my preference is New Castle, or Guinness.  It adds a lot of depth to the flavor.  I also add a few more rough chopped onions, and a few cloves of garlic, just peeled smashed.  Rosemary, thyme, and a couple bay leaves, and a good dash of pepper.  If you can always strain the sauce into a bowl for serving to get these extras out and leave only the au jus.

I also sear my roast before adding it to the slow cooker.  Just rub it on all sides with some salt, pepper, rosemary, and thyme, and then sear each side of the meat in a hot pan with a little oil.  Takes about 10 extra minutes of extra prep but helps seal in those juices to the meat.  Also, like any beef, let it rest for a 5-10 min before you cut it so all those juices don't just go spilling out.  Favorite bread for this a crusty ciabatta bun, with provolone melted on top.  YUM!
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2017-10-11T22:33:19.763

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5783186.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe and it's an easy favorite for the family. Instead of using beer though, I substitute Burgundy and use a can of Beef Consume. I also add about 1-2 tablespoons of garlic to this dish. When the meat is almost all cooked I cut it up/shred it and let it simmer in the juices more. Once we're ready to eat I toast the buns, put the meat on them, then add provolone cheese on top and reinsert them in the oven until the cheese melts. My husband loves it and we always have more for leftovers the next day.

Super easy. Always a hit. You can doctor it up with a few garlic cloves (just leave whole) some hot pepper (flakes or canned or fresh) but it just never fails. It really only tastes "beery" if you use an IPA or something with a lot of hops. Good with cheap beer or a stout.

text:
Amazing and restaurant like!  Took suggestion of others and used 1 can beef broth, 1 packet Lipton Onion Soup, Guinness beer, garlic powder and Worcestershire sauce.  Buttered rolls with some garlic powder and wrapped and baked in 350 oven for about 10-15 minutes.  Assembled sandwich with beef, sautéed onions and topped with provolone cheese.  Wrapped sandwich and returned to oven for about 5 minutes.  Au Jus gravy on the side.  Delicious!!!!!

text:
My boyfriend and I absolutely loved this recipe. I didn't change much -- except I rubbed the roast in a mixture of salt, pepper and garlic powder before putting it in the slow cooker. For the beer, I used Guinness. I cooked the meat (3.5 lbs) for about 8 hours on low. Meat was extremely tender and flavorful.  I also added a slice to provolone cheese about 5 minutes into the 10-minute bake  time for the Italian rolls. So good and so easy. I will make this again.

text:
Great base recipe! I made a few changes. I started by adding salt and pepper to the roast and searing it on all sides. When I threw it in the cooker with the liquids I also added minced garlic,  rosemary, thyme,  and a couple dashes of worcestershire. I cooked in high for four hours then removed the roast,  sliced it up and returned it to the slow cooker on low for another two hours. Came out fabulous, the whole family loved it!

I have made this several times and each time it was great. The meat can be browned with some flower before cooking but is not necessary. I added one onion chopped and about 5 cloves of garlic. text:
Holy French Dip!! This was so good I'm already looking forward to the next time I make it! 

I used a craft beer, Firestone 805. I also added about 3 cut up garlic cloves and fresh cracked pepper to the slow cooker and at the end I added a little more salt because I felt like it needed it. Then I shredded the meat in the crock pot and let the meat sit in the juice while I toasted the buns. Then I put the meat, some grilled onions I made, and some provolone cheese  on the buns and let it melt for 5 more minutes in the oven. Yum, yum...Thanks so much for the great recipe.

text:
It was fairly good, I did cheat and make French onion soup the previous day so I used the leftovers from that instead of the canned stuff.  I cut up the meat, as suggested from others, and let it rest in the mixture on warm for about an hour before serving, I know if I had just served it immediately it would have been very tough but allowing it to cool in the broth made it very tender.  I made my own rolls but that is a different recipe all together.  Next time I will have to add a bit of port to make the broth more au jus like.  All in all it was good.

region:

country:
None
text:
This is delicious and super easy. I used a 2.5lb chuck roast that I rubbed down with garlic powder, onion powder, pepper, and olive oil. I let it rest for about 20 minutes and put it in the crock pot with a stout , a splash of worchestire sauce, and the other ingredients listed. I didn't have a can of beef broth, so I used 1.25 cups water and 2 beef bullion cubes. I sliced the meat thin and then let it cook for about another hour in the au jus. Hubby put it on the rolls with provolone and broiled them. They were phenominal. Will definitely make again and again.

I will make this again, but using a Chuck Roast instead of the bottom round I used. 7 hours in, on low, it was dry and like a rock. I wasn't honestly sure that it would be salvageable, but I took it out, let it rest and cut it very thin, threw it back in the crock pot for another hour.  It ended up turning out fine, but like I said, I would use Chuck next time. I used a full can of Yuengling and did add some seasonings, like fresh Thyme and Garlic. The Au Jus that this made was delicious! It is a keeper

text:
This was amazing! I read many of the reviews and took the advice to season the roast. I used a chuck roast, seasoned both sides with pepper, garlic powder, onion powder and worcestershire sauce. I used a can of cambells french onion soup, cambells beef consomme, and a bottle of guiness. I cut up a french bread loaf, toasted it under the broiler, added meat and provolone cheese, back under the broiler for a few minutes and there you have it! My husband is extremely picky when it comes to french dips and he LOVED this. Just dipping pieces if the french bread in the au jus was delicious ! Will definitely make this again!

text:
I made this as directed with the exception of using a few dashes of  Worcestershire sauce to deepen the flavor and a packet of Au jus prepared as directed instead of French onion soup since it contains MSG which I am allergic to. We found it delicious and versatile, being able to switch up the sandwiches using different types of cheese and bread. We like crusty baguettes while our kids like soft rolls. My husband requests this often and it's great for a crowd, game day or when someone moves and you need food for your helpers.

text:
I rated this 4 stars because my meat alone seemed a bit dry.  However, served with the juice (dipping bowl for each person), this sandwich was delicious and oh, so easy to make. I rubbed the meat with about a clove of minced garlic and poured a 1/2 to 1 tsp of Worcestershire sauce over the meat once it was in the slow cooker. I followed the advice of others and shredded the meat about 30 mins. before I was to serve it and put the shredded meat back in the warm juice for that extra time.  I will certainly be serving this again.

So easy and it was so good! I also added garlic, onion salt, minced onion and used Guiness for the beer. Once cooked, I sliced and added back into juice while I prepared the buns. I buttered both sides of the hoagie bun and put them in the oven for not quite 5 minutes to toast up. I will season a bit more next time, but a hit at my house!

country:
None
text:
This was fantastic!!!

After making this a few times, we have changed a couple of things (Trust me, we've made this  A LOT).

We add a beef bouillon because we find it lacks a bit of flavour without it.  I also use a package of Knorr's Dry Onion Soup because I can't find anything canned here in Ontario, Canada.

After the meat is pretty much cooked, we will take it out, cut it up and put it back in for another hour or two so that it can soak up more of the juice.

We've never had an issue where the meat has gotten dry.

My son who is 6 is the one who asks for the "Beer Dip" all the time lol

text:
Just great. Made it with the french onion soup recipe, cooked it in the oven instead of slow cooker for 7 hours at 100 deg C. I kept turning and basting every few hours. cooled, sliced and left it in the au jus overnight (along with the caramelized onions from the onion soup). sauteed mushrooms and peppers and piled them on the french bread, cheese (I used gouda) with the meat and onions. served with fries and au jus on the side. I offered some bbq sauce to add to the sandwich, but the meat turned out so well that no one wanted it. I'll definitely be making it again.

text:
DELICIOUS!! I'm not a fan of French Dip with au jus but wanted something different to try with my rump roast so I made these for my hubby. Omgosh am I glad I did, they were delicious! 
Make sure to make the changes suggested by Chef Mickey because I feel they enhanced the taste of the au jus - I made my own beef broth by mixing 4tbsp beef boullion granules (for a heavy beef broth) with hot water, make sure the bullion is fully dissolved, and then I poured it into the dark beer and dried onion soup mix prior to adding my spice rubbed rump roast to the crock pot. 
This recipe (again, with Chef Mickey's changes) made a new fan for French Dip sandwiches!! A new family favorite that I will be making many more times in the future!!

text:
Wish I could give this more stars!! I just made this tonight and it was absolutely amazing! After reading reviews I made a couple changes. I used a round bottom roast that I sprinkled garlic and onion powder on last night. I then started it this morning and let it cook for about 9 hours. I used Beef Consomme, French Onion Soup, and Guiness Beer with a splash of Worcestershire Sauce. When it was ready I buttered some French Rolls and put them in the oven for a sec to brown a little bit, then I took them out and put the meat and provolone cheese on them and put it back in the oven until the cheese melted and served it with the juice. De-freakin-licous! The hubby LOVED it too!!!

text:
I made this for supper tonight, I used New Belgium 1554 beer, 1 10oz. can of Beef Consumme, 1 clove of garlic, and pepper. I sauted onions and mushrooms, toasted buttered kaiser rolls with provolone cheese melted under the boiler.  I sliced the roast two hours before dinner and turned the slow cooker to low.  The meat was immersed in the juice, it was a superb dinner and so easy to make.  It was added into the rotation of dinners.

userID:
8364525
Display Name:
KYPepper

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/121.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely wonderful!  I've made this several times and have never been disappointed.  I use only about 8 oz of a dark beer (really makes the au jus terrific).  I add the following seasonings to the roast before cooking: minced garlic, black pepper, Worcestershire, and a dash or Kitchen Bouquet.  When the roast is finished I remove from the cooker and let it rest before slicing.  After I slice it, I dip the meat back into the cooking liquid of the crock.  Then I lift it out with a slotted spoon onto sliced french bread that are arranged on a baking sheet.  I add provolone cheese to the top and slide under the broiler until the cheese begins to brown.  Strain the au jus and you are ready to eat.  Garlic steak fries are good served with this meal.  This is favorite meal in my household!  I love making it.

text:
This was very easy and the au jus it makes was so good!  I used a rump roast but I think a different cut of meat would have been better.  The rump roast shredded instead of sliced and was a bit tough.  I cooked mine on low for 5 hours and it was done...I think 7 would be way too long.  I used a can of Michelob Lite (that was the only beer in the fridge that my husband wouldn't disown me for using in a meal) and added about 7 shakes of Worcestershire sauce and a little bit of garlic powder and onion powder to the meat.  I served over rolls that I toasted slightly in the oven.  I also added some mozzarella to a few of the sandwiches.  Yummy!

I'm giving this four stars because I had to add seasoning to it to make it really taste good. Now, I did have to substitute the condensed french onion soup for a onion soup packet so that may have made a difference.

This was delicious! I used a rump roast that I trimmed, and for the beer I used Newcastle. I added one clove fresh chopped garlic and about a tsp of liquid smoke. I took french rolls split in half and lightly dipped them in the juices and placed them on a hot non stick pan an placed a lid smaller than the pan to slightly squish the bread and trap the steam from the juices to steam the bread for a minute or two. AMAZING. I used provalone cheese also :) So easy!!

text:
I used a chuck roast - advised by the butcher because it shreds easier and is tastier because of the fat though I did cut out as much fat as possible. I followed a lot of the additions that were mentioned - it was very tasty!! Even my son who is a great cook thought it was one of the best sandwiches he has eaten!! It's a tradition to have RB dip sand. at our Christmas gathering - no more buying prepared beef (that sold for $9. - $10. a lb.) I got the chuck roast on sale for $3.29 a lb. and it was much tastier!! Thanks lonwolf32 & all the reviewers!!

Display Name:
Staci

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This would have been 5 stars but I added things not on the recipe. Even with my alterations I thought it needed a little salt or other seasoning when eating it, but my husband advises not to add any extra seasoning to the pot since you can always add more seasoning at the end but you can't unseason it. 

From advice of other reviewers, I added:
1 T worcestershire, 1/2 t onion powder & 1/2 t garlic powder.

I wanted a whole meal out of it so I also added skinned halved red potatoes & baby carrots (whole, except thick ones I cut in half) to cook for last 4 hours. It was the perfectly cooked. Glad I'd read advice on a few pot roast recipes before making this. (They said if the veggies cook the entire day with the roast they get mushy.)

My husband is the cook, I fail miserably usually. He makes everything great & competed in BBQ competitions for years. Last time I tried a french dip crockpot recipe he wouldn't even try it. But the aroma when he got home from this one hooked him. He went back for thirds, then drank the juice left on the plate, then went back to get the onion pieces with a fork! Our one year old made "mmmm" noises when eating the veggies, which she has never done before. I'd say it was a success!

text:
I gave this 4 stars instead of 5 because the recipe does not call for any salt or pepper.  So, I rubbed the roast down with both before putting it in the slow cooker.  Even with this, the Au Jus is not very salty, but it does have good flavor.

Next time I cook it, I will take the recommendation of other users and use a dark syrupy beer like Guinness.  I had a Bud Light on hand and used it, but the Au Jus was kind of weak and would have really benefited from a darker beer.

Otherwise...

The meat was really good and the toasting of the buns was a very nice touch.

I absolutely loved this. So easy and the flavor was great. I followed the recipe exactly except I used London Broil. It was on sale and the butcher said it was a good substitute. Next time, I think I will make French Onion soup out of the Au Jus like another user suggested.

Yummy!  Because I leave for work 12 hrs before we eat, my crock pot dishes always end up dried out.  With this I cooked it over night for 7 hrs and then cut it up in the morning and threw it in the fridge all day.  I reheated for about a 1/2 hour.  Nice and tender.

text:
This was so delicious!  I took other's advice, added 2 cans of Campbells consomme, a packet of Lipton Onion Soup Mix, and I used an Irish Stout beer.  I also made a rub of garlic, onion salt/powder, sea salt, and crushed peppercorns.  For leftovers, we actually had these on the Hawaiin Rolls & oh my was it wonderful! The flavor of the beef w/the sweet of the roll was just so good and gave it an extra yum factor.  Next time I make this, we'll just put on the Hawaiin Rolls.

This was such a big hit!  I did make a few changes though.  I used vegetable broth because I didn’t have beef; I added a few shakes of onion power, Garlic power and Worcestershire sauce.   When I came home I sliced up the meat and throw it back in the sauce for another 30 minutes.  I buttered the rolls and sprinkled a little garlic power over the butter then added provolone cheese till it was melted.  My husband said it was restaurant quality!

userID:
4410930
Display Name:
crec
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I know people think that making lots of changes and then reviewing a recipe is wrong, but I made quite a few and these were some of the best sandwiches I've ever eaten; reminiscent of Portillos in Chicago.  I skipped the beer because I didn't have any, which may be why I needed to add other flavors.  Seasoned a chuck roast with spicy Montreal steak seasoning, added whole fresh mushrooms, a whole onion, two whole cloves of garlic, a little Italian seasoning, and sea salt to taste about an hour before shredding the meat and returning it to the juices for a few minutes.  Made the meat a sort of cross between French dip and Italian beef.  We fixed our sandwiches on bollio rolls with provolone. Fantastic!

text:
Yes, this was easy, but if you do not season the roast some it will be blah. I sliced 2 onions and placed them in the bottom of the crock pot, poured liquids in and added roast that was rubbed with pepper and cajun seasoning. I also added 1 tbsp of minced garlic and worcestershire sauce to the liquids. After 6 hours removed the roast to carve, when I tasted the juice it was still just okay, added garlic powder, better than boullion beef base and horseradish, much better. Served on toasted buns with horseradish mayo.

text:
This is one of my favorite recipes!  I don't add the beer, so I replace it with more beef broth.  This tastes WAY better than anything made with the powdered soup.  The condensed soup makes all the difference.  My whole family loves this recipe!  We serve on crusty french rolls with provolone cheese.  I also brown the beef in a frying pan first, I think it helps the flavor.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and three year old loved this!  It is great to have delicious French dip sandwiches so easily and cheaply.  I made this recipe exactly as described, but found that it lacked some flavor when I tried it (that is why I gave it four stars), so I added significant amounts of salt, garlic powder, and worcestershire sauce to the au jus, then I sliced the meat and returned it to the crock pot, letting it sit in the juice with the crock pot on warm for about half an hour.  Turned out wonderful.  The recipe cost me about $18 to make, which is pretty good, considering it fed my little family of three twice.  Definitely one to try if you like French dips!

text:
My modifications: I used a 4 pound chuck roast. Didn't have beer so I just added more water along with the beef broth. Used the lipton's onion soup packet mix instead of condensed french onion soup. I couldn't quite slice the meat b/c it was too tender and ended up pulling off chunks for the sandwiches. I toasted the bread in the oven and placed the chunk of meat on it and put it back in oven to melt a little havarti cheese. The results: It was so delicious! The dinner table was silent (in awe) as everyone ate!

My family and I can't find the words to describe exactly how delicious this was! YUM!  However, I LOVE beer, but I could definately taste beer in the juice.  No worries, I added another can of the French onion soup.  I also took the advice of others and added a little onion powder and garlic salt.  The meat was fall apart tender!   I'm going to make this again and again...Can't wait to share it with my friends for The Superbowl!  Thanks for the recipe!!!!!
Update:  I use Shiner Bock beer and it's PERFECTION!  I think my family would eat this every night if they could.

text:
This recipe was delicious! I couldn't find a rump roast so ended up with a 2.5 lb London Broil and since it's just my husband and I, that was more than enough. I cooked it for 5 hours, sliced it thin and put it back in the juice and turned it to "warm". I was worried it was going to be too dry, but turned out very juicy! I toasted the buns under the broiler topped them with meat and Provolone cheese and put them back under th broiler to melt the cheese. Yum! I will definitely use this recipe again! Thanks!

I tried this recipe as written, but I didn't care for the beer-I preferred the au jus flavored with red wine and soy sauce, as well as the the garlic and onionand fresh cracked black pepper-so much richer flavor.  I also preferred the chuck roast, and shredding the meat as opposed to slicing it. Thanks for the great idea!

Crust your bagels in the broiler until golden brown.  Add your french dip mxiture w/juice.  Top with gorgonzola cheese and broil until cheese is bubbling. Garnish with fresh parsely and serve immediately.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I couldn't wait to get my hands on this sandwich after reading all the rave reviews and I thought for sure all the people that said this was bland didn't do something right. But, like others, I was a bit disappointed with the final result.  I followed the recipe to a "t" and would give it a 3 as written. I will never rate a recipe after I tweak it, because I do not think that is fair to the author, and I don't think allrecipes should allow that! Well, they were spot-on, it was very bland!  Once I tweaked it, it turned out DELISH. My way I would give it a 5. I added Worcestershire sauce, garlic powder and MORE beer.  I think what happens is the beer goes into the crock pot right away, and then by the end of 6-7 hours, the beer taste is ALL GONE, and YES I used a dark beer...no light stuff.  So the key here is to ADD THE BEER TOWARDS THE END of cooking time to keep that yummy taste, and then I think this recipe will become a 5!

i love this recipe but i do use a few changes. i do the chuck instead of rump, use i can each of beef broth, consomme and french onion soup, i add about a 1/2 tablespoon of beef bouillon, and just when it's almost done i throw in about 2 tablespoons a fresh chopped garlic. my entire family loves this recipe. we make a double batch and eat leftovers for a few days. when i do use beer in it, i use a Guinness stout.
