text:
This was amazing, and I did take suggestions from other reviewers, mainly the cutting and adding back for the last hour part.  When I cut the strips I was worried because they were dry, but after another hour in the juices after being cut they were perfect! We ate this three nights in a row (the third night I turned it into goulash).  By the time its cooked 8hrs you shouldn't taste the alcohol at all, and I used a Harvest Moon Pumpkin Ale, nice a dark and very rich flavor (it is a bitter pumpkin ale, not like the more seemingly sweet ones, hence I used it to cook with, and it worked SO WELL) : )  Thanks for the recipe, I'll make it again.

text:
I have a new slow cooker, and this was the first recipe I tried with it. I thought the beef was tasty and tender, and the dipping sauce was just as I remembered it when I had beef dip years ago. I added garlic powder to the beef roast before cooking, and I used 1/2 bottle of beer as some other reviewers suggested. There was no way the beef was able to be sliced, but shredding was fine. I cut the buns in half, toasted each, then heated the meat on one side and melted cheddar cheese with green onion on the other - and to serve, put the meat half and cheese half together. YUM.

text:
One of my favorite slow cooker recipes! Not only are the flavors great, but you don't need to do any prep work, just toss it all in the pot. So if you don't have a lot of time, say you want something to make in the morning, go to work, and come home to this is perfect. I also serve it how I have seen others do, on a toasted roll with melted cheese (swiss, american, provolone, any kind really) on top. Great for lunch the next day too!

My family LOVED this recipe and practically licked the crock pot clean. I used Guinness beer and followed the recipe only adding some garlic salt and powder. Following some of the other reviews, I pulled the roast out and sliced it then placed it back in for about 45 mins, great flavor. I served it on french bread with provolone cheese! YUM!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This had a wonderful flavor but I think rump roast is the wrong cut of meat.  I had to modify the ingredients based on what I had on hand.  I boiled 3 beef boullion cubes and 12 oz. of water.  I mixed a package of french onion dip powdered mix with a can of golden mushroom soup, I added that with a bottle of Amber Bock and the beef broth to the crock pot and let it cook for about 5 hours on low.  Took it out and let it rest for a few minutes, then sliced it in small thin pieces and added it back to the juices for one more hour.  Then made the sandwiches as the recipe suggests.  I made french onion soup with the remaining broth, the next day...now that was awesome!

I have made this recipe countless times for football games, etc., and it's always a hit!  My husband and our friends LOVE these french dip sandwiches, and it's an easy recipe to feed a crowd with.  I use Guinness as the beer of choice, and add provolone cheese to the rolls.  Even better, the leftovers make an equally tasty meal the next day - just throw the leftover beef and juices into a pan, thicken with flour, and serve over egg noodles!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a 3 lb top round. Wanted a lot of au jus, so I used two cans of broth, a packet of dried onion soup mix, half a bottle of dark beer, and about a can of water. Got a late start, so started the cooker on high for a couple hours then turned down. After it was cooked through but still tough I thinly sliced up the beef and put it back in for a couple hours hoping that would help it get tender in time (total time 7 hours). It worked! Everyone loved it and I have lots of au jus for the freezer. Served with provolone, a topping of sauteed mushrooms, green peppers and onions. Also had plain broccoli, and then spinach sauteed with red bell pepper.

Great for left overs if there are any!

text:
Excellent recipe.  I made this recipe for family after my daughters baptism and did not have any left.  Everyone loved it.  I did however make modifications after reading many reviews.  I used sirloin tip roast, french onion soup, beef consomme, and guiness beer.  I also added beef broth (for extra juice), which I am glad I did.  I cooked the roast the day before serving for about 6 hours on low, then put it in the fridge overnight.  I took the roast out the following day, then sliced it and cooked it on low for an additional 5 hours.   This will definately be added to my favorite list!

text:
I made this for a small super bowl party at the house and everyone loved it!  My husband is a tetotaller 100% and so he is very sensitive to the taste of cooking wine, or any other alcohol used in cooking.  I was apprehensive about this recipe, but after reading the reviews, I figured I would give it a shot. My husband never knew there was beer in the recipe, and he absolutely loved these sandwiches.  I made a few mods to it though. I used butter and a garlic spread on the rolls, and I added a small thinly sliced piece of provolone to each sandwich.  It was delicious!!!  I love this recipe and will def. use it again!!!
Review:

This was very disappointing. This is hardly what I would call a french dip- the meat was the consistency and had the flavor of pot roast. If you do make this, be sure not to follow the recipe, as it has virtually no flavor. I would suggest adding salt, pepper, garlic and onion powder...otherwise you will be eating a very bland piece of pot roast on a roll.

text:
French dip is my husband's favorite sandwich. He liked it but did not love it. Made this last night with a 3 lb rump roast and thought it was just ok and more of a pot roast sandwich. Followed original recipe but added garlic, onion, and pepper. Followed others and took out and sliced meat 1.5 hrs before done and then put it back to pot. It became more tender. The aus jus was bland, so very thankful I had a packet of powdered aus jus gravy to dip. Served it with provolone cheese on toasted french bread.

text:
My husband loves this sandwhich.  I did add a hefty tablespoon of chopped garlic (we love garlic alot) and added a bay leaf as well. I also add browning sauce as suggested by others. Then I cut sandwhich buns and butter both sides and put the meat on the buns and top with a slice of provolone cheese.  I put it in the oven on broiler setting for 2 mins!  A great warm hearty meal on cold winter nights!

text:
This recipe by itself was very bland. I made it with a all the changes that others have recommeded. Added half the beer, 1 tsp of worchester, garlic, onion powder, salt to taste, can of mushrooms and it was still bland. After it was finished, I pulled the roast out and simply shredded it and added bbq sauce. I piled the beef on the french bread with butter, topped it with cheese placed it in the broiler until the bread got toasty and the cheese melted. It was good but with all the changes it wasnt the same recipe.

text:
Fabulous!  Did it exactly as the recipe stated. When I made the sandwiches, I spread the bread with a combo horseradish/sour cream mix, added fresh (raw) onions, topped with whole green chilies, then smoked gouda cheese and put them under the broiler to melt.  They were phenomenal.  Best french dip sandwiches we'd ever had.  The sauce makes wonderful au jus!  The smoked gouda, raw onions and green chilies topped it off for a fabulous lunch-time meal! Definitely a keeper.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was certainly easy to prepare.  I took the advice of some other reviewers and sliced it up a couple of hours prior to being done and placed the slices back into the pot of au jus.  I was a little worried about being "beery" because I could smell the beer almost until it was done, but in the final product no "beer" taste.  My only complaint of the recipe was that the au jus was really flat and one demensional in flavor.  I did not add salt, pepper or sasonings to the mix because honestly with the soup and beef broth I thought it might be a little on the salty side.  Next time I will really season up the meat and sauce good.  Thanks for sharing.

Display Name:
Joy Zarate

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We really love this recipe.  I have made it a number of times and have perfected it to the way we like it.  I don't add beer anymore.  More times than not I'm out of beer and I think it's still great without it.  I use a packet of onion soup mix instead of the can.  I cook mine on low overnight for about 12 hrs. (I have an old crockpot so I think mine takes longer than some of the new ones) then I take it out, slice it and return the slices to the crockpot for another couple of hours.  When I serve it, we try and use sourdough rolls.  I split the rolls, butter them, add a sprinkling of parmesan and toast them in a pan.  Then we add provolone cheese.  When I serve the au jus, I add a splash of soy sauce to each dish.  Yummy!  Everyone looks forward to having this dish and I love it because rump roast goes on sale frequently BOGO.

userID:
690458
Display Name:
Homestead Grandma
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7

54
favoritesCount:
291
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2612522.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was AMAZING!  Couple of minor changes I made:  I used a tri-tip roast which I coated with a spice rub (found on this site) minus the salt that the rub called for and let that sit for a couple of hours.   I then seared it on the hot grill then placed it in a small roasting pan with the liquids and roasted it outdoors in the same grill.  I kept the lid closed to keep in the smokiness and the temp stayed around 325-350.  I added water occasionally to keep the juices from drying out.  It didn't take long to cook.  Took it out at rare to medium rare and by the time I finished slicing it (thinly!) it was a perfect medium to medium rare.  Very tender and so flavorful!  Served the slices over toasted hard french rolls (crispy on the outside, chewy and dense inside) to which I added provolone cheese and a little mayo.  Had made enough to freeze for later but we ended up eating it all weekend for lunch and dinner and now it's all gone!  We just couldn't eat anything else while it was available!  Outstanding French dip.  As good or better than any I've had in a restaurant.  Absolutely to die for!  Thanks for sharing this one!!

text:
I really really wanted to love this, as it is so easy (and apparently lots of other people love it!).  I followed the recipe and the advice of many many prior reviewers and added some seasoning (garlic etc) to the base of 1 can beef consomme, 1 can beef broth, 1 can french onion soup, and, after much debate, 1 12 oz can beer.  DH and I LOVE beer, but for some unknown reason, neither one of us likes food cooked in/with beer.  I ended up using it and I wish I hadn't.  I even purposefully used a yucky light beer someone had left here hoping it would do it's tenderizing thing, but not affect the taste.  Neither one of use really liked this and I ended up throwing out the leftovers AND the au jous.  This will not be a repeat in our house.  It's really a "1" for us, but I have a hard time rating it that low since there's nothing *wrong* w/it, it's just didn't appeal to our personal taste.

text:
I love, love, love this sandwich!  I omit the beer; tried it once and just don't like it.  I don't replace the lost liquid with anything else but I do use a 14.5 oz. can of Swanson's broth instead of the 10.5 oz. the recipe calls for.  There's plenty of au jus left for dipping.  Instead of baking the french rolls I place them buttered side down on a griddle and toast them that way.  Thanks for an awesome recipe!

text:
I didn't know if I should review this recipe since I had to make some changes. I could not find condensed onion soup so I used progresso onion soup, added a lipton onion soup packet, a couple shakes worchestire sauce, some garlic, and my husbands homemade beer. I had to use smaller cuts of meat and could only find shoulder. It turned out pretty good. I did have to add more salt and I don't think the meat was the best to use since it wasn't fatty enough. That being said, it was a good recipe and I can't wait to try it again with the right ingredients and the right cut of meat.

None
text:
This was so good and so easy. I did as other's suggested and sliced the beef about a half hour before serving. Perhaps it was the cut of beef I used, but my beef was not very tender. I was hoping for really tender meat. Next time I'll try a different kind (I used Tender Chuck Roast because my grocery store didn't have Rump Roast). Also, I added some garlic powder, minced onions, worstershire and liquid smoke to mine (just a tad of each). We both devoured every bite and there wasn't much left today to bring for lunch. I saved the juices (beef broth/onion) and plan to use those later in the week for a French Onion Soup as another reviewer had suggested. Oh, and I put some shredded mozzarella on the buns and it was awesome! Thanks Robyn for the easy recipe and thanks to the other reviewers for the suggestions on how to improve it.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/170132.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
MMMMMMMmmmmmmm!!! This beef comes out so tender and delicious. I used about a 3.5lb chuck roast (well trimmed), 1 can French Onion Soup (onions removed, yuck can onions), 1 Can Beef Consume, seasoned roast w/ a little sea salt/pepper, garlic powder and worcestershire sauce. After 6 hours I removed the beef and cut it up, I then strained the liquid twice and placed everything back in the slow cooker for another hour. Also, I tasted the au jus at that point and had to add a bit more seasoning to it. Served on buttery toasted French rolls w/ melted mozzarella cheese and a side of vegetables. BIG winner at my house! Who knew something so good could be made at home by an ordinary cook?!? This is going in the Sunday rotation, it's so nice to come home from church and smell the wonderful aroma!

I usually love any recipes I get from Allrecipes, but I'm completely baffled by this one.  I'm no amateur cook, yet I could not have been any more disappointed with this recipe.  The meat was dry and tasted like an ordinary pot roast.  The au jus was salty and bitter--and I DID follow the directions carefully and accurately.  I finally strained out the meat and used it in BBQ'd beef sandwiches.  Now, THAT was great.  I'm sorry, I can't and wouldn't recommend it, but I wouldn't let that stop me from using lots of other recipes on your site because many of them are all they promise.

This recipe is so good and so easy.  You could serve this to a crowd in the same amount of time that it would take you to make it for just a few people.  I love putting this on to cook before I leave to go somewhere and when I get back, dinner is done!

I could eat the juice as just a soup at that point and be happy.

Wonderful recipe! My husband could not stop talking about..I used Guiness for the beer, and french onion soup mix. I also seasoned the roast with garlic powder, salt and pepper before putting it in the slow cooker. I adjusted the seasoning of the broth to my taste once the roast was cooked. I cooked the roast on low for about 10 hours, and the meat was so tender it fell apart. Definitly will make again and again! thanks!!

text:
This was perfect AS IS, but if you need to add anything for your individual tastes, go for it.  We used a local porter (Polygamy Porter, a Utah product) for the beer for stronger broth, and added a slice of swiss cheese on the sandwich for extra flavor.  The au jus makes a great gravy for hot roast beef over biscuits, too!  Just add a roux made with flour and butter and cook to desired consistency -- no additional seasonings required.

text:
This is the first recipe I made with a slow cooker (well, besides queso). I must say, this is a keeper! I used the exact amounts in the recipe (my roast was more like 3.45 pounds) and added fresh mushrooms and a sliced onion to the broth. Use good beer - I had some Newcastle Brown Ale on hand that did the job. Towards the end when the roast started to get tender, I added a bit of corn startch to thicken up the broth. Served with rolls, mashed potatoes and fresh green beans - fantastic!

text:
great recipe.  I used an eye of round roast.  since I can't have MSG, I sliced a large sweet onion in the bottom of the crock pot.  I seasoned the roast with emeril's essence, salt and pepper and 1/4 cup red wine.  I then covered the whole thing with a 32 ounce beef broth (MSG free).  the onions were great on the sandwich and we took some advice from previous reviewers and melted cheese on the top under the broiler.  YUM!

country:
None
text:
This was a huge hit at my house.  I can hardly wait until tonight when we have leftovers!

I did add a package of au jus mix, substituted a package of onion soup mix for the condensed soup, beef consumme for the broth, and used a Shiner Bock amber ale.  And since they were on sale, I used a chuck roast.  

After cooking for about 4 hours, I took the meat out and sliced it very thin with an electric knife and then put it back in the slow cooker.  About an hour before serving, I sliced some mushrooms and added them to the pot. I also skipped the butter on the french rolls, split and toasted them and we topped each with a slice of provelone and then spooned on the french dip.  The meat was tender enough to cut with a fork.

This will absolutely be on a regular rotation at my house!

text:
I have been using this recipe for years.  I do add more spices to the au jus, otherwise there isn't a whole lot of flavor.  This is the one recipe my husband always requests.  I like to make homemade potato chips with my mandolin slicer to go along with it.  Just use Lawry's seasoned salt on them for a different flavor.  I also toast my french rolls with provolone instead of butter.  I think I will try the dark beer as one reviewer suggested for added flavor.  This will always be in my top 5!  I saw one reviewer had a problem with the meat falling apart, but I actually prefer it...the more tender the better!  I love love love this.  Try it!  You can always make adjustments to suit your own taste but this is a great base recipe with few alterations needed.

text:
YUMMY!  Use 1 can beef broth, 1 can beef consomme, 1 soup can water, 1 envelope dried onion soup mix and throw in veggies that I had around (celery, carrots, onion).  We've had this several times using whatever roast is on sale.  Great au jus to dip your sandwich in, my husband ate the broth like soup.  Have taken the crock pot to my mom's for dinner and everyone enjoyed it.  We use crusty rolls and provolone cheese and melt it under the broiler.  Mmmmmm...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As usual, I didn't have everything called for in the recipe. Having no french onion soup, I had to substitute 1 pack dry beefy onion soup, 3 beef bullion cubes, a dash of garlic powder and a cup of water. The only roast I had was a chuck which wouldn't slice so I shredded it and dumped it back in the pot with the juice. Took the rolls, split them, spread them with butter and a little garlic salt, put some shredded mozzarella on top and stuck them under the broiler until toasty and bubbly. The guests dipped their rolls in the "au jus soup" and said it was heaven! This recipe would be excellent for a beef and noodle soup. None of us could detect a beer taste and usually if there's beer in a recipe, my granddughter just turns her nose up. She loved this one! Thank you Robyn, I will use this recipe many times!

text:
It "ain't" quick but it sure was easy and it's worth the time to make! The meat came out very tender and tasted really, really good.  I melted swiss cheese on the bread. I did add onions in the sauce at the begining. I don't know if that changed the flavor of the dip or not but I didn't care for the au jus as much as the regular kind I'm used to. I give five stars for the sandwich but only two for the dip. The leftovers were even better the next day. I cut up the meat and left it in the slow cooker with the sauce, put it in the refer and let it soak overnight. The flavor of the meat the next day was even better! Wow! Great French Dip sandwiches!  Thanks for a great recipe Robyn!

TERRIFIC RECIPE!! text:
Wow!  What a delicious, and easy recipe!  I made this over the LaborDay weekend, and enjoyed every bite!  I did use a can of Coke, instead of beer, as others had suggested, and it was fabulous.  I also studded the roast with garlic cloves (5 of them!), as is always done when a roast goes into my crock pot...for fabulous flavor.  After eating these yummy sandwiches for 2 days, there was still extra juice, along with a little meat which then became the base for the most delicious beef stew I've ever tasted!  This recipe is definitely a keeper, and will be enjoyed on many a weekend to come...thanks for the awesome recipe!

YUMMMMMMY!  I made this with a sirloin tip roast as I couldn't find any rump roasts.  THIS IS 5 Star restaurant quality. The only alteration I did was I ran the french onion soup through the blender as I don't like chunks of onion but I love the flavor.  I have 3 dogs and they all got some of the broth with their dog food and they also give you 5 stars!  Ruff! Ruff!!   Can't wait to make it again.  THANK YOU SO MUCH!!

text:
The way I made it, it's a meal in the crockpot. Since I used frozen meat I put the crockpot on high.  Only used 2# of beef, but kept all other ingredients the same. An hour before we were ready to eat I put a quarter of a box of linguini into the liquid and 1/2 hr before serving added 2 cans of mushrooms, liquid and all.  Delicious & easy!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipes was delicious.  I added mushrooms, sauteed onions, a splash of Worchestire sauce, and packet of McCormick's Au Jous sauce along with the indicated ingredients.  I let it cook for 4 hrs., then I sliced the meat in half, and let it cook another 4 hrs.  When I removed the meat for slicing, I let it sit untouched for ten minutes so it can asorb the juicies to prevent dry meat. After slicing, I placed the slices back into the pot for another ten minutes scooping it out with the mushrooms and onions. The meat was juicy, and the gravy was flavorful and delicious. Sooooo good!

text:
This recipe is a real winner - everyone loves it, and it's so easy. My only tip is that you need to cook it for the MAXIMUM time stated - two times I cooked this and the meat wasn't tender enough to shred.  Not the recipe creator's fault - just the cut of meat.  So cook this one a loooong time.  Once you do, though, it's terrific.

This is a very easy recipe. I used dry onion soup mixed in water and it worked fine.  We ate it the first night sliced with veg and potatoes and the second night on a bun dipped in the juice. Will difinitely make this again.  It is so easy. If you have it sliced, make sure you soak the slices in the juice first or it may be a bit dry.
